articles.headline: Hoping Jobs for India Follow, Modi Clears Investors’ Path
articles.snippet: The changes are the most significant loosening of market restrictions since India began economic liberalization, with foreigners now permitted to own 100 percent of many companies.
articles.abstract: The changes are the most significant loosening of market restrictions since India began economic liberalization, with foreigners now permitted to own 100 percent of many companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian government announced sweeping changes on Monday to throw open its economy to foreign investment, providing a new path for global titans like Apple and Ikea to capitalize on the country’s growth, the fastest among the major emerging markets.
articles.byline: By Geeta Anand and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: Jeep That Crushed Anton Yelchin Had Been Recalled
articles.snippet: The actor’s Jeep, which rolled backward and killed him, had been recalled for a gearshift problem that could leave it accidentally in neutral.
articles.abstract: The actor’s Jeep, which rolled backward and killed him, had been recalled for a gearshift problem that could leave it accidentally in neutral.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 2015 Jeep Grand Cherokee that rolled backward down a driveway and killed the actor Anton Yelchin early Sunday was a model that Fiat Chrysler has recalled for a gearshift issue that has confused drivers, leading them to accidentally leave the car in neutral when they think it is safely in park.

articles.headline: Smugglers in West Bank Open Door to Jobs in Israel, and Violence
articles.snippet: A thriving industry allows West Bank residents to get past what Israelis call a security barrier. It has a dangerous side effect: Attackers sneak through as well.
articles.abstract: A thriving industry allows West Bank residents to get past what Israelis call a security barrier. It has a dangerous side effect: Attackers sneak through as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAHIYAT AL BARID, West Bank — At 4:15 a.m. on a dead-end street, a 33-year-old Palestinian man came running from the shadows between buildings with a rickety wooden ladder. He slapped it against the hulking concrete wall and climbed up, hoisting himself the last six feet because the ladder was too short.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Rami Nazzal

articles.headline: Apple May Soon Open Retail Stores in India
articles.snippet: While the stores are not expected to have a large impact on the company’s market share in India, some analysts say the change could help Apple attract the top tier of India’s smartphone buyers.
articles.abstract: While the stores are not expected to have a large impact on the company’s market share in India, some analysts say the change could help Apple attract the top tier of India’s smartphone buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After months of delays, Apple is likely to open its first retail stores in India, a fast-growing market for smartphones where the American technology giant has little presence.

articles.headline: Why Uber Keeps Raising Billions
articles.snippet: An unspoken strategy behind Uber’s aggressive fund-raising may be an effort to starve its rivals of capital.
articles.abstract: An unspoken strategy behind Uber’s aggressive fund-raising may be an effort to starve its rivals of capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: It feels like almost every other week there is a new headline about Uber raising more money. “Uber Closes $1.6 Billion in Financing.’’ “Uber Turns to Saudi Arabia for $3.5 Billion Cash Infusion.’’ Last week, we got this one: “Uber to Raise Up to $2 Billion in Leveraged-Loan Market.’’

articles.headline: Donald Trump Starts Summer Push With Crippling Money Deficit
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump began June with $1.3 million in campaign cash, trailing Hillary Clinton by more than $41 million, the biggest disadvantage for a major party’s nominee in recent history.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump began June with $1.3 million in campaign cash, trailing Hillary Clinton by more than $41 million, the biggest disadvantage for a major party’s nominee in recent history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump enters the general election campaign laboring under the worst financial and organizational disadvantage of any major party nominee in recent history, placing both his candidacy and his party in political peril.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Rachel Shorey

articles.headline: After Brexit Vote, a Choice for Europe: Move Forward, or Fall Back
articles.snippet: Europe itself lacks a firm democratic foundation, leaving voters to express dissatisfaction only by supporting extremist political movements.
articles.abstract: Europe itself lacks a firm democratic foundation, leaving voters to express dissatisfaction only by supporting extremist political movements.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Hints He May Fund Race Himself
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, in dire financial and organizational straits, suggested he might tap his personal fortune “if need be” to be competitive in November.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, in dire financial and organizational straits, suggested he might tap his personal fortune “if need be” to be competitive in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Las Vegas last week, Donald J. Trump’s Nevada headquarters stood dark. A sign taped to the door declared that it had moved, with “no forwarding information available.”
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: F.A.A. Issues Commercial Drone Rules
articles.snippet: Previously, companies had to apply for special permission to operate drones. Now a range of businesses may use drones under 55 pounds, but not for package delivery.
articles.abstract: Previously, companies had to apply for special permission to operate drones. Now a range of businesses may use drones under 55 pounds, but not for package delivery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government on Tuesday made it much easier for companies to use drones for a variety of tasks, including aerial photography and emergency response.
